awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamics and Propagation of Surface Instabilities in Soft Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
When soft materials are compressed, their surface often spontaneously forms wrinkles, creases, ridges, or folds with periodic patterns. These patterns are called 'surface instabilities'. Over the past several years, there has been significant interest in understanding how surface instabilities form, as they are ubiquitous in biological systems and have found wide use in engineering applications ranging from microfabrication to soft robotics. However, nearly all of the past studies have focused on understanding how surface instabilities form under very slow compression, or have neglected the dynamics leading to this event. This award will investigate how surface instabilities form and propagate across the surface of the material as a result of fast compression or impacts. The speed of the event causing the instability is critical as it yields fundamentally unique phenomena, which are prevalent in most physical systems, but still not well understood. The improved understanding gained as part of this fundamental research will impact a broad range of applications. For example, because of the role of surface instabilities in friction, this research will positively affect engineering applications with moving soft materials in contact. It will also lead to improved understanding of the dynamics of sandwich beam composites, and to improved impact absorbers, shock protective systems, and novel soft electronics devices. In addition to the research goals, this project has a significant education and outreach component that will positively affect students from K-12 through graduate levels, and will increase the involvement of underrepresented students in STEM fields.

The research objective of this multidisciplinary, collaborative project is to investigate the initiation and propagation of surface instabilities in soft materials under dynamic loading, using a combined theoretical, computational, and experimental approach. Experimental characterization will be conducted using a combination of drop tower, high-speed video, and laser ultrasonic test methods. Dynamic surface instability propagation will be modeled analytically, and computationally using nonlinear finite element techniques. This project will provide significant intellectual contribution by answering open questions including: What are the conditions for initiating the propagation of surface instabilities, and how do they propagate? How does the propagation of surface instabilities lead to material failure? And how can the propagation of surface instabilities be manipulated? More generally, as there have been almost no investigations into the dynamics of propagating surface instabilities, this investigation will open a new class of instability-based surface waves and provide an improved understanding of dynamic phenomena in soft materials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Elastic waves propagating along surfaces have been a topic of significant interest for over a century, with applications ranging from geophysics (e.g. earthquakes) to signal processing (e.g. cell phone filters). In recent years, the mechanics of surface instabilities, or "wrinkles", in soft media, such as elastomers and gels, has received massive interest. However, despite this interest, these phenomena have been explored almost exclusively in quasi-static, or "slow", settings. The high-speed dynamics of surface wrinkles is a highly challenging problem due to their nonlinear behavior and the multiple-length and time scales involved. In this project, we studied how surface wrinkles due to instability form and propagate in soft materials with stiff surface films as a result of high-speed impact. 

We found that for systems that have been slightly pre-wrinkled, their dynamics can be predicted by superimposing the "low-speed" model on high speed simulations of their base layer, albeit the observed amplitude is smaller than was predicted by these models. Later, we found that systems without this pre-wrinkling exhibit even richer dynamics, which are not captured by the low-speed model, and lead to the formation and evolution of multiple wrinkling modes. These multi-wrinkling-mode dynamics remain a subject for major investigation because, while low speed models predict nonlinear effects, such as period doubling, that lead to the formation of multiple modes, in our high-speed impact cases, we did not reach the level of deformation needed to trigger such effects. In addition, we also uncovered a major role that viscous behavior of the substrate plays in the high-speed wrinkling dynamics. For instance, in addition to possibly contributing to the observed reduced amplitude wrinkles, analytical estimates also suggest that viscoelasticity can explain a steady downward shift in the centroidal wrinkling wavelength with increasing impactor speed. 

These fundamental studies are important for several reasons. First, the dynamics of such soft material systems were found in our experiments to be qualitatively different than similar, well-studied, systems such as elastic films floating on liquids. Second, an improved fundamental understanding of these systems has the potential to enable a range of new applications. Such potential applications include novel impact-resistant soft composites, soft elastic wave signal processing devices for use in flexible electronics, and new soft layered flexible composites for use in aerospace systems (e.g. long flexible wings). This study may also contribute new understanding to high speed friction dynamics in systems where layered composites are used. 

This project also directly contributed to student education, and the results of our studies were disseminated to communities of interest. Multiple graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, and multiple undergraduate students were supported by this grant. The project participants also participated in outreach events, such as the K-12 Discovery Days event at the University of Washington, where topics related to soft materials and wrinkle formation were demonstrated to the public. Finally, a peer review article was published related to this work, which was accompanied by a frontispiece image highlighting the article. 


Last Modified: 02/26/2020
Modified by: Nicholas Boechler
